title: SEC never finalized repo disclosure rule that would give investors more info
text:
The Federal Reserve said it injected of $53 billion into U.S. short-term money markets on Tuesday to stem a spike in interest rates for repurchasing agreements, or repos - the overnight funding market that felled Lehman Brothers in 2008 and MF Global back in 2011.

But the Securities and Exchange Commission failed to finish rules after the financial crisis that would have mandated more disclosure about companies’ exposure to repurchase agreements.

Investors would know more about banks and companies’ exposure to repos if the SEC had finalized a disclosure rule first proposed in 2010 in response to the financial crisis.

In 2010, the SEC proposed a rule in response to Lehman’s lack of disclosure of its Repo 105 liabilities. Called “Short-Term Borrowings Disclosure,” the SEC’s proposal said “a critical component of a company’s liquidity and capital resources is often its access to short-term borrowings for working capital and to fund its operation.”

Events during the financial crisis, and now, show that these types of arrangements “can be impacted, sometimes severely and rapidly, by illiquidity in the markets as a whole,” according to the SEC’s proposal.

The Fed’s action this week was its first overnight repo auction since 2008 and it came after short-term repo rates surged to their highest level in years. The overnight borrowing rate — one that bond dealers, hedge funds, and other market participants are charged behind the scenes to borrow funds for a short period, in return for highly liquid collateral such as U.S. Treasurys — jumped to a high around 9%. The Fed’s action pushed it back to a desired 2%-2.25% range but the New York Federal Reserve said it would carry out a second overnight repo operation on Wednesday —up to $75 billion in repos.

See also: Wall Street raises questions about Fed’s late action on funding squeeze

Gregg Gelzinis, a research associate at the Center for American Progress, an independent nonpartisan policy institute, told MarketWatch, “It’s malpractice that a decade after the financial crisis, regulators still don’t collect the data necessary to fully understand and map the risks in the repo market. The SEC has failed to finalize a 2010 proposal that would provide much better public disclosure on companies’ use of repo borrowing.”

Read: Reforms haven’t eliminated risk of another Lehman-type failure

In a comment letter to the SEC at the time of the proposal, then Sen. Carl Levin wrote, “Inaccurate accounting treatment of repurchase agreements was not confined to Lehman Brothers.” Levin noted that other investment banks, such as Bank of America BAC, +0.20% and Citigroup C, +0.88% had acknowledged during the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission hearings after the crisis that they also recorded repos as sales versus financing.

Accounting rules permitted the repo transactions to be treated as sales. That allowed Lehman to report a lower asset balance — it reported the Treasurys and mortgage backed securities as sold not lent — since the cash it received in the borrowing was less than the value of the assets it had pledged.

However, the cash it received was not recorded as a loan, and the obligation to repay the loan and repurchase the Treasury security was not recognized as an increase in its liabilities. Instead, the right to repurchase the collateral was recorded as a new asset, a derivative right to purchase securities in the future.

On Oct 31, 2011 MF Global, a global broker-dealer led by former New Jersey Governor Jon Corzine, collapsed. MF Global could not meet margin calls on European sovereign debt it used as collateral in repo transactions. MF Global had recorded profit upfront from investing in the sovereign bonds and then using them as collateral in so-called “repo-to-maturity” contracts, also recorded as sales of the assets, and also did not fully disclose its resulting repo loan liabilities.

Gelzinis says the recent spike in repo rates may have had a few idiosyncratic causes, and certainly doesn’t signal the type of run seen in 2007-2008, “but regulators should take this week’s turbulence as an opportunity to re-evaluate the fragility of this short-term funding market.”

In tri-party repos, which Lehman and MF Global used, a clearing bank provides collateral valuation, margining, and services to ensure terms of the repo are met. The average daily cash value of reverse repo agreements collateralized by U.S. Treasury securities, federal agency debt securities, and mortgage-backed securities for the week ended Sept 11, 2019, according to the Fed’s “Factors Affecting Reserve Balances” report, H.4.1, was $291.974 billion. That’s $9.727 billion less than the prior week but more than the same period last year.

In a bilateral repo, the lender drives the valuation and margin requirements on collateral pledged by the borrower. Gelzinis told MarketWatch, “The Office of Financial Research recently started collecting more repo data, but even this expanded data collection fails to capture the massive bilateral segment of the repo market. Bilateral repos, a huge segment of the market, are still in the shadows. They should collect more and better data on the market and also consider proposals to fundamentally restructure the market to address the ongoing systemic risk it poses to the financial system and broader economy.”
description: The SEC never finalized a post-crisis rule that would give investors more info about companies’ exposure to repos and impact spike in borrowing rates
